Fields.DialogueText: Finally find a space for the bell?
Right at the end of my stern, Captain. It won't do any harm there. Looks pretty, though.
You're the ship, Exeter. Just remember that we've got to live here.
Always! It wouldn't be generous of me to give you more problems.
Funny you should mention that. INPF code gives their officers the right to surrender excess or unusual cargo to their Belles.
"Unusual?"
That's a quote.
Many of us can be rather a handful, I admit. I think the submarines tend to be inclined toward skulduggery...

Fields.MenuText: Don't let them hear you say that.
Stealth is certainly their area of expertise.
At least you come by your treasure honestly.

Fields.DialogueText: We're all in this together, Captain! No harm in a little good-natured ribbing.
As direct confrontation is mine.
Oh, the rumours I could share about certain of my sisters...
You have a good heart, Exeter. Just make sure you leave space for the rest of us.
Always, Captain! And you've a special place in it.
On the ship, I mean.
That too.
Right.
So. Morganas?
Right! Of course.
@BATTLE
Captain, I need your opinion on this.
It's very pretty.
Well, of course it is. I wanted to see if you thought it appropriate to hang here in the bridge.
Where did you get a tapestry at sea?
Had it in from Rougemont, back at my namesake. The castle's been in such a sorry state over the years... I should just expropriate the contents and have done with it.

Fields.MenuText: Is that legal?
I'm sure the city would be pleased to help.
You can't just fill your hull with art treasures.

Fields.DialogueText: I should hope so. It's a crime to let your history fade.
Maybe I'll get a letter to the council. No looting or fire to worry about out here...
If they're safe and out of the way, I can certainly try!
Well, it looks quite fine where it is. It's nice to have something to look at between skirmishes.
Oh, I quite agree, Captain.
What do you mean?
What do you mean, what do I mean?
*ALARM*
Good thing we're both in the right place at the right time.
But not on the same page...
You were looking at me a certain way just now. I can't really put my finger on it...
@BATTLE
What's in the box this time?
Ah, Captain! Attentive as ever to the ship's cargo.
I'm given to understand that's a virtue. Something about Belles being unconventional?
Well, you won't find anything unconventional about this. I thought the crew deserved something nice as a token of my appreciation.
You have to be one of the most appreciative Belles I know.
I don't need much myself, but my stipend gets reduced if I don't use all of it. May as well put it to use for my loyal crew!

Fields.MenuText: Or for charitable purposes.
Don't spoil them.
What do they think of it?

Fields.DialogueText: This is a charitable purpose! Besides, INPF code forbids external donations.
That's what I'm for! You keep them in line, Captain.
They love it, if our meetings are anything to go by. It warms my heart when I see them wearing something I've given them.
So what's the treasure this time?
Go ahead and open a box, Captain.
Compasses? That's pretty useful. Not that we'd ever have to abandon ship and navigate that way.
Just in case, Captain. And each has the coat of arms of my namesake. So you remember where your home is.
Well, our home away from home.
Quite. Come to think of it... I got something especially for you, too.
Other than the bell?
Much more portable, Captain, I assure you.
Ugh... Morganas. Join me in some shooting?
@BATTLE
Me first? I haven't a clue what you're talking about.
I read the manifests every morning, Captain. I know when you've requisitioned something extra.
Back to reading people's mail again, Exeter? And assuming mine concerns you?
I'm not reading it! The manifests are open to you and me. Besides, am I wrong?
No, you're absolutely right. This does concern you.
I knew it! Well, what is it? Come on, tell me!
*ALARM*
It's a secret for now.
How rude to tempt a lady!

Fields.MenuText: It's not my fault you're nosy.
Apparently the Morganas are on my side.
I thought you were a knight.

Fields.DialogueText: To battle, then. We'll sort out the gifts after the shooting stops.
All right, guilty as charged, but you're still a tease.
It's the 20th century, Captain. Knights can be ladies!
So nefarious! An enemy in our midst all this time...
All right, you first.
You first, Captain. Don't forget it!
@BATTLE
Damn! They caught us napping.
Keep that gift in your heart, Captain! No force in the world will keep me from getting it to you.
@BATTLE
You made a promise, Captain!
I know, I know. Here - open it up.
Pleased!
I was going to give you a crowbar.
Belle, remember? Nails are barely an inconvenience.

Fields.MenuText: Well? What do you think?
I most certainly did.
You're right. The blacksmith did.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, the balance... the inlay... it's beauitiful!
Where in the world did you find this? No - it's newly forged!
Oh, very funny. Someone had to commission it!
I know you already have a sword, but I figured you could use a backup.
A backup? This puts my Royal Navy blade to shame! It's taller than I am!
I knew you'd like it. Though I'm curious about how you'd use it in battle.
For you, I'd cleave a torpedo in two. It's certainly big enough for the job.
Captain! You didn't!
Oh! And now I've got to give you my gift. It's no greatsword, but I thought it'd do.
Ooh. This is the heaviest teapot I've ever seen.
I scrounged some scrap metal from one of our battles, Captain. You pour your tea, you think of me.
This was... part of you?
That's not weird, is it? We Belles have kind of a different way of thinking about our hulls than you humans and your bodies, and...
It's not so unusual. People have known to exchange locks of hair during courtship.
That's what this is, then? We're in agreement?
Always, Exeter.
Eeeee! Rwy'n dy garu di, Capten!
Whoa! Do knights... hug?
They do now.
Come and join me, Captain!
Morning exercises?
With my brand-new greatsword, of course. Borrow my old one.
Is that... possible?
It won't disappear if I let go of it. Come on, try it out!

Fields.MenuText: What do I need to know swordplay for?
All right, like this?
Only if I get a shot at that greatsword.

Fields.DialogueText: The better you can defend yourself, the safer you'll be. I can't be around all the time.
One hand, Captain. Whichever is your dominant one.
I think your gift would break first! My saber is... different.
How should we go about this?
... Much as I might like to be.
Just follow my lead, Captain. It may feel light, but you'll notice its weight quite soon.
You weren't kidding.
Morning stretches are a little more strenuous with a blade involved, no?
If we're going to tire me out with a sword, I'd rather be dueling.
Ha! You'll get your wish for a fight once we catch up to the Morganas. But a duel might not be a bad idea...
@BATTLE
Have you noticed the crew talking?
Rumours about us?
Nothing I can't dispel at the next meeting.
By chance, did these rumours start at such a meeting?
Some of the crew noticed an extra spring in my step lately. I couldn't keep it from them forever.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if they've noticed one from me.
Couldn't you?
I guess it was bound to get out eventually. Try to keep it quiet?

Fields.DialogueText: That was the next thing they brought up. We've got some observant crew aboard, Captain.
Could you?
Yes, yes, professional propriety and all that.
Come to think of it, I did hear a couple of the pilots talking about something strange.
Strange in what way?
People are talking about some mysterious packages that have come in with recent mail deliveries. No return addresses.
What was in them?
That's the mysterious part. Books, sweets, pictures... all normal things.
Curious. All the more reason to monitor the manifests, then.
We'll discuss it after the fight. I think we're about to intercept an enemy group...
@BATTLE
Catch anything anomalous?
Just one. I'm holding it in the brig for now.
Was it addressed to anyone specific?
Oddly enough... It was addressed to you, Captain.
That's chilling.
Generosity is all well and good, but in a war zone we have to know where it's coming from.

Fields.MenuText: Did you open it?
We ought to toss it overboard.
Who's the unlucky sailor who gets to check it?

Fields.DialogueText: Wouldn't dream of it, Captain. And not just because I respect your privacy.
We could, but I think we'd be throwing away a valuable clue.
Na! Don't even joke about that. It's got to be one of us.
Well, it'll have to be me who takes a proper look.
No, Captain. Allow me.
Aren't I supposed to be able to deal with it? That is why you picked me, right?
You're resistant to their tricks, sure enough. But we still ought not risk exposure. I'm a Belle. I can take it.
*ALARM*
Looks like our new pen pal is here.
Could be, Captain. Let's tread lightly.
@BATTLE
Can you hear me, Captain?
Loud and clear, Exeter. Let's start the recording... now.
Ahem... This is HMS Exeter, pennant number 68. I'm initiating contact with the unaddressed package in my brig.
Exeter's captain presiding.
Swordpoint contact confirmed.

Fields.MenuText: Don't just poke it, Exeter. Open it.
Maintain distance.
Copy that.

Fields.DialogueText: So much for keeping things clinical.
Overruled. Physical contact is necessary for further study.
Moving to physical contact.
What's inside?
... How old?
... An old issue of Look magazine.
July 1939. Hitler's nephew has an article.
Oh, I've been meaning to read that one for ages. The address must have gotten left off.
I take it the experiment is over, then.
*ALARM*
It'll have to be. I thought for sure we were on to something...
@BATTLE
Have you ever felt you were going to sneeze and then failed to?
Or watched the clouds on an overcast day and waited for rain that never came?
This tea needs more tea. I didn't steep enough.
I get what you're saying, Exeter. I thought for sure we'd learn something from all this.
Oh, we did. Hitler's favorite dessert is whipped cream.
Still. I'm ordering all mail held in the brig for a week if it's improperly addressed.
That's going to cause a right stomachache.
I'm not keeping it in the galley.
Ha ha. The ship doesn't correspond perfectly to my human form, you know.

Fields.MenuText: Thank goodness for that.
It does hurt when you're hit, though.
Wouldn't it be easier if it did?

Fields.DialogueText: Let me stop you right there before your mind goes where I know it's going.
Oh, certainly. Not always in the same places, though. Sometimes it's all over.
For you to understand, maybe. Leave us Belles to our instincts.
It does worry me, though, Captain. Do you remember in Le Morte d'Arthur when King Arthur lost his throne?
Vaguely. Wasn't he fighting Lancelot or something?
You're suggesting we're looking in the wrong place.
Which gave his son Mordred the opening he needed for his rebellion.
There's something we're missing, Captain. When Morganas are abroad, that's dangerous.
*ALARM*
Speaking of Morganas...
No great loss. I'd messed this pot up anyway.
@BATTLE
I had the most interesting conversation with York the other night.
For a given value of "conversation."
Don't be horrid, lamb. She told me - in her own way - that she's gotten unaddressed mail as well.
Can this wait until our spar's over?
Mmm... No.

Fields.MenuText: Showing off again?
It's hard for me to duel and talk at the same time.
What if I just focus on the fight?

Fields.DialogueText: Says the one with the greatsword!
Precisely what we need to train out of you!
Then I expect it'll be much less interesting. I do so love our chats.
Whoa! At least get your cat out from underfoot.
Scouse! Oh, I wondered where you'd gotten to.
Hissing again. That cat used to like me.
Shame, that. I know how much you love the little beasts.
Yes, well. Unless he's planning on joining in, he'd better scram.
*ALARM*
Such a lovely little luck charm... but he can be a right coward sometimes.
There's the klaxon doing our work for us.
You'd think he would have gotten used to it by now.
@BATTLE
Captain, we've got Morganas!
What!? Get the planes ready in case the weather permits.
We can't! You told the crew they were due for maintenance.
I said nothing of the sort!
Never mind that now. Looks like Morgana mist up ahead.

Fields.MenuText: You would have been the first to know if your planes were grounded.
From whom!?
They're out of their minds. I issued no such orders!

Fields.DialogueText: Then why wasn't I?
From you!
Then who did?
Let's both calm down. We won. We're all fine. That's not up for debate.
Do you think it has something to do with the strange mail?
Iawn... I'm sorry, Captain.
@BATTLE
What the hell happened back there, Captain?
I could ask you the same thing. I didn't give those orders.
Maintenance and pilots said they had written orders!
Morganas... that's the most likely culprit, Captain. Unless we're looking at sabotage.
I don't think that likely. But until we're sure, I'm delivering all my orders in person or through you.
Bloody inconvenient, that.
That's what we've got the loudspeakers for.
Suppose I'll just have to get used to your voice.
Cruel fate, that.
I'll learn to live with it.
I wish you wouldn't call them that, Captain.
You hold your group therapy sessions with a lot of crew. I don't know of a more efficient way to comb for a saboteur.
I keep my eyes open for any sort of... oddity. But those sessions are sacred, Captain. They're an outlet for grief, frustration, trauma, or simple boredom.

Fields.MenuText: Even if the answer could be hiding right under our noses.
I understand. I just wish there were a better way to solve this.
Their lives could be at stake. Your life could be at stake.

Fields.DialogueText: You remember how York's old captain turned himself in. I believe everyone has a breaking point. Ours must be further than... whoever's.
You'll have to send them to the ship's doctor one at a time like you've been doing.
I'm a Belle, Captain. I'm at stake every day.
Maybe we could send Scouse around to sniff for traitors.
Did the crew finally convince you he could predict the weather?
Heh. His powers of perception lie elsewhere.
How are the interviews coming?
If anyone thought they were being scrutinized... they would only be driven away.
He rolls onto his back and scoots around when it's about to rain, and you can't possibly tell me otherwise.
He's hissing again. At least it's not at me.
His Morgana senses are almost as good as mine.
Pets really can be useful.
He's my second in command, and you'll refer to him as such.
@BATTLE
How're the papers today?
I'm catching up from a while back. Coastal towns coming under attack; those that don't dry up and move inland, that is.
Well, we can't be everywhere at once.
Still. You'd think one of these days... wait a minute.
What do you see?
Oh, that's a shame.
What?

Fields.MenuText: I mean, that's just icing on the-
I'm looking at the obituaries.
A really unfortunate coincidence.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, tell me or I'm letting everyone know how loudly you snore.
Someone you knew?
Well, spit it out.
The blacksmith died.
What blacksmith?
The one that made your sword. The one I gave you.
Morganas.
Morganas?
*ALARM*
Speak of the devil...
@BATTLE
This isn't right, Captain.
I'll say. This tea's oversteeped again.
Besides that. My sessions haven't been nearly as well attended lately.

Fields.MenuText: They'll come back.

Fields.DialogueText: It's serious, Captain. Some of them have been on edge lately.
It's this whole ship, Exeter. People are swapping mail just to be sure the words don't change on them.
Superstition. I've got no use for it.
Except when Scouse tells you it's going to rain.
That was uncalled for, Captain.
So was that plane fiasco. You get to the bottom of that yet?
I've told you before that's not what the sessions are-
Well, maybe they should be!
... I'm sorry. I-
@BATTLE
There's my Morgana senses, Captain. Clearly they're throwing us all for a loop.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe some of the crew don't need them anymore.
You take attendance at these things?

Fields.DialogueText: If they didn't, they'd tell me.
I know the names of all my crew and when I've talked to them. You should too.
How are the waters?
Clear.
Good. Nothing worse than facing these things in choppy seas.

Fields.MenuText: Are you going to say something?
I'm sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: You've stated your business.
So am I.
I'm waiting.
I was wrong. I implied you weren't committed to the mission, and you are.
I wouldn't be opening my heart to the crew if I weren't.
Catching the crew in a lie. Hearing someone admit to treachery. I maintain that the group talks are sacrosanct. But...
No, you wouldn't.
I was afraid.
Of what?
Like me, you've been waiting to see what happened.
And thinking we just had to be ready for it.
It's the Round Table all over again. Arthur refused to see Lancelot or Mordred for what they were until it was too late.
I suppose that makes me your Guinevere.
Heh. Always fancied myself more of a Gawain than an Arthur.
Compassionate? Unstoppable? Beautiful?
Do go on, my Captain. You'll make my ego so big these Morganas will aim for it.
@BATTLE
What story? And aren't we about to go into battle?
King Arthur. He died, right? What happened to his knights? His kingdom? His sword?
We'll have to muse on that later. The enemy aren't nearly as well read as we.
@BATTLE
Talk later. Spar now. I need to unwind from that scrap.

Fields.MenuText: If you say so.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha!
Hyah!
Whoa!
Scouse, get out of the ring!
Oh, he's going to make a mess with that newspaper if we don't scruff him.
Wait... hold him there. Is that the newspaper from...
What is it?
-The blacksmith.
This is from a while back. When I saw the obituary for-
How did the story end?
Are we so sure?
Come on. I've got time to beat you senseless before we go back to the mystery.

Fields.MenuText: I'm getting tired of these delays.

Fields.DialogueText: And I'm getting tired of beating you. The quicker we finish this, the quicker we can solve both problems.

Fields.MenuText: What's the score?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm undefeated, but who's counting?
Who was found dead... before I gave you that sword.
Then who made it?
Who the hell was I writing to?
... All in favour of leaving my haunted greatsword here and sealing the room off? Aye.
Meow.
Aye.
What did you tell the crew?
Nothing. I posted a sign outside the training room that said electrical work was being done.
Better than a warning. As long as someone's taking care of things everyone can relax.

Fields.MenuText: That's what we're out here for.
I still think I should have said something.
Except the ones who are actually taking care of things.

Fields.DialogueText: The land still has its own problems, Captain.
And risk someone getting curious? Dim Diolch.
Perception is reality, Captain. We learned that the hard way.
What I want to know is what the sword's meant to do if it's Morgana in origin.
Let me look at it, Captain. I've always let you use it in our sparring sessions.
Think you might sense something in it?
I might. Some kind of aura or something that made you-
I didn't need an evil sword to snap at you, Exeter. We all make mistakes. That was mine.
... Sorry.
We'll have to table the investigation, though. Seems some Morganas are catching on.
Don't give them too much credit.
You say that. Perhaps we haven't been giving them enough.
@BATTLE
Oh, Duw hollalluog, I've been so blind.
Get a look at that sword?
Well, Scouse is getting extra dinner tonight, that's sure.

Fields.MenuText: Always trust a cat, eh?
What did he see?
Get to the point.

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes I think they see things even Belles can't.
Let's just say it's a good thing he can't read.
I'm making it. That's when I first started to suspect something was up.
I took one look at the inlay when you gave it to me, Captain, but I didn't give it any thought.
What was wrong with it?
There were... signs. Symbols. A script humans can't read, but that Belles and Morganas can.
What did they say?
The sword's a beacon, essentially. It draws Morganas to us... and tells them our address, so to speak.
So the bogus orders...
God only knows what the crew have been seeing. No wonder the sessions have been drying up.
That still doesn't explain the sword.
Who knows, Captain? The Morganas  devour and learn from everything and everyone in their path. Not unreasonable to assume one might have picked up smithing.
*ALARM*
Keep it.
What!?
Just for now. In the meantime, you can start reading the crew's mail again.
@BATTLE
I'm afraid I have to voice concerns once more, Captain.
This is serious, Exeter. We need to go back through every scrap of mail since I gave you that sword.
I know. I just wish there were some way to do it without... prying.

Fields.MenuText: You're a fast reader. It'll be over before you know it.
You could always let me help.
I'd say this qualifies as a good reason.

Fields.DialogueText: That's hardly my concern, Captain.
No, Captain. I have to be the one to do this if Morganas are involved.
I don't disagree with you...
It's for the crew's own good.
It's dishonest, Captain. How long before we start justifying greater infringements for lesser reasons?
You know, I've been reading your Arthur stories too. Remember Gawain and the Green Knight? He cheated.
... Yes, but he won that enchanted girdle by remaining chaste. And he lied about having it.
And he acknowledged it, and wore that mark for the rest of his life. But he was still good. He simply didn't want to die.
Seems I need to start taking my own advice. It seems so obvious hearing someone else say it.
Especially if that someone is me.
Any perspective was welcome. But it does help to hear it in the voice of a loved one.
*ALARM*
Let me know if you find anything after the battle, won't you?
I think I already have.
@BATTLE
Anything?
A bit.

Fields.MenuText: A bit of British understatement if ever I heard it.

Fields.DialogueText: We've mastered at least that.
What did you find?
Family. Friends. Homes and aspirations... drifting further apart. All of it Morgana in nature. I could feel their influence in every letter.
To think they'd devote so much to messing with the crew that way.
They never sleep, Captain. They're despair incarnate. All the time in the world, and they... they pour it into...
Come here.
Thank you, Captain. It'd be odd if this didn't hurt my heart. But now we can end it.
I should have destroyed that sword ages ago.
We had to be certain it was the source, Captain.
Well, we are. Now what?

Fields.MenuText: That bad?

Fields.DialogueText: Honestly? We're lucky we caught it when we did.

Fields.MenuText: Just a bit?

Fields.DialogueText: Quite a bit.
*ALARM*
Do you remember what ended up happening to Excalibur?
@BATTLE
It's going to be an especially ugly day.
Positive as always.
Make no mistake, Captain. I've never been more confident in my life. Just to be in the presence of these... these...

Fields.MenuText: Breathe, Exeter.
Say your worst.
These...?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'll breathe fire.
... No. You'd never recover.
Seirff. Gwrachod. Diafoliaid.
Do you want to be Sir Bedivere, or shall I?
You gave me the sword in the first place. It's mine to return to the Lady of the Lake.
Or Morgan le Fay.
Make it count.
Appropriate. You'll want your binoculars ready.
"And then he threw the sword as far into the water as he might."
What do you see?
Well, she certainly didn't catch it in her hand.
Then we start as we mean to go on.
@BATTLE
Feel better?
Much. How's the crew been?
Less scarce at meetings. The mail's stopped being evil, so that's helped.
Now that we're not magically broadcasting our address to those who would abuse it.
I've heard of Morganas attacking mail ships for psychological warfare.
And cousin Nubian figured out that they can imbue objects with their evil.
At a cost.
We all have a base understanding of our uglier sisters. But we're learning more every day.
We'll see that it only works once.
I suppose Scouse must be terribly satisfied with himself.
Looks like everyone got what they wanted in the end. With one exception.

Fields.MenuText: We're learning, at least.
I suppose it makes sense that you Belles would share knowledge.
Despicable.

Fields.DialogueText: I gave him a whole fish for his trouble.
Oh? What's that?
I still owe you a gift. One that isn't cursed.
Anghofiwch amdano. You're alive and well, and that's enough for me.
Is it?
I can think of a few other things I'd like. Let's get rid of these Morganas and I'll tell you all about them.
@BATTLE
For you, Captain.
That looks smaller than a church bell.
I was feeling sensible today. Open it.
A Royal Navy sword... like yours?
From a living vendor this time, thank God.

Fields.MenuText: Or a cleverly disguised corpse.
It's so light.
Now we can fight on equal terms.

Fields.DialogueText: If Morganas are anything, they're vain. They won't try the same trick twice once discovered.
For now, Captain. Just wait until we get some exercise in with it.
Mmm... a level playing field, certainly. I can't dance circles around that bloody greatsword anymore, at least.
Another Excalibur?
Right now?
Leave the past in the past, Captain. Your sword should have a name... an identity... all its own.
Not right away. It'll come to you one day... perhaps when you least expect it.
The best things often do.
*ALARM*
And the worst.
Come join one of the best on the bridge, my love. There's work to be done.
I'm noticing a distinct lack of a church bell at your stern.

Fields.MenuText: I'd prefer not to.

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't realize I'd fallen in love with Bartleby the Scrivener.
Sweep the wreckage overboard, then?
I thought of it. But then I thought better of it. Here.
Is this...?
I'm no smith, but I hammered something resembling a medal out of it. The whole crew is getting them.
That's thoughtful of you. Not dress legal, of course.
I seem to remember someone convincing me that chivalry was more of a set of guidelines. Why not uniform?
A set of guidelines you happen to exemplify.
Why, thank you, Captain! I do consider myself quite well dressed.
Dressed for battle?
A knight always is. Let's prove it here and now.

Fields.MenuText: It wouldn't have. I've seen you in training.

Fields.DialogueText: You should see how fast I am. I reckon I could catch a bullet with enough practice.

Fields.MenuText: I'm struggling to think of a weakness you might possess.

Fields.DialogueText: Any of my guns or my deck itself. Everywhere else is armoured up tight.
An unfortunate casualty. It took a direct hit in our last engagement... thank goodness. Imagine if it had hit somewhere vital.
@BATTLE
